title: [ENH] LOOKOUT: "Leave-one-out kernel" density estimates for outlier detection
body:
LOOKOUT is a new approach to detect outliers using leave-one-out kernel density estimates and extreme value theory. Outlier detection methods that use kernel density estimates generally employ a user defined parameter to determine the bandwidth. Lookout uses persistent homology to construct a bandwidth suitable for outlier detection without any user input. 

R code:
https://github.com/sevvandi/lookout

The R implementation depends on some additional packages (which either need to have equivalent python counterparts, or the functions be re-written), specifically:
- [ ] `phom <- TDAstats::calculate_homology(dist(X), format = "distmat")`
https://rdrr.io/cran/TDAstats/src/R/calculate.R (R)
https://github.com/scikit-tda/ripser.py/blob/master/ripser/ripser.py (python)
- [ ] `RANN::nn2(x, k = nn)$nn.dists`
https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/RANN/versions/2.6.1/topics/nn2 (R)
should be able to use sklearn.neighbors.NearestNeighbors (python)
- [ ]  `evd::fpot(log_dens, qq, std.err = FALSE) `
https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/evd/versions/2.3-3/topics/fpot (R)
https://github.com/iagolemos1/thresholdmodeling (python)
^ new dependency, but most likely need to re-write as it's not been maintained
- [ ] `evd::pgpd(-log(kdeobj$lookde), loc = qq,...` The Generalized Pareto Distribution
https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.stats.genpareto.html

The major uncertainty in the scope of this work is in `evd::fpot`, Maximum-likelihood fitting for peaks over threshold modelling, using the Generalized Pareto or Point Process representation.

Reference:
Kandanaarachchi, Sevvandi, and Rob J. Hyndman. "Leave-one-out kernel density estimates for outlier detection." Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics 31.2 (2022): 586-599.
